expanded_description: Motion with constant acceleration is one of the most important topics in kinematics. When acceleration is constant, we can use a set of powerful equations—the kinematic equations—to predict and analyze motion completely. This includes free fall, vehicles accelerating uniformly, and many other real-world situations.

core_concept.principle: Constant acceleration motion occurs when an object's acceleration remains the same throughout its motion. This produces predictable patterns: velocity changes linearly with time, and position changes quadratically with time. Four kinematic equations describe all aspects of this motion, allowing calculation of any unknown quantity from known values.
core_concept.explanation: When acceleration is constant (uniform acceleration), motion follows specific mathematical patterns that make analysis straightforward. The velocity-time graph is a straight line (constant slope), and the position-time graph is a parabola (curved). Five key variables describe the motion: initial velocity ($v_i$), final velocity ($v_f$), acceleration ($a$), time ($\Delta t$), and displacement ($\Delta x$). Four kinematic equations relate these variables in different combinations. Given any three variables, you can always find the other two. This systematic approach makes constant acceleration problems very solvable. Common examples include: free fall near Earth's surface (constant downward acceleration $g = 9.8$ m/s²), cars accelerating or braking uniformly, objects on inclined planes, and projectiles (vertical component has constant acceleration). Understanding constant acceleration is essential because it's the foundation for more complex motion analysis and appears throughout physics.

sections.introduction: Constant acceleration motion has distinct features that make it recognizable and analyzable using specific mathematical tools.

key_concept.definition: Motion has constant acceleration when the acceleration value remains the same throughout the motion. The acceleration doesn't change in magnitude or direction. This produces linear velocity change and parabolic position change.
key_concept.context: Constant acceleration is an idealization, but many real situations approximate it well: gravity near Earth's surface, friction on uniform surfaces, constant engine thrust, steady braking. Recognizing constant acceleration allows using the kinematic equations.

principles.statement: The defining feature: acceleration has the same value at all times during the motion. $a = \text{constant}$
principles.application: If $a$ doesn't change, motion is uniformly accelerated.
principles.example: Free fall: $a = -9.8$ m/s² constantly. Car with constant gas pedal: $a = +3$ m/s² constantly. Not constant: car with varying gas pedal, ball on spring (oscillating acceleration).

principles.statement: Under constant acceleration, velocity increases (or decreases) by the same amount each second: $v = v_i + at$. This is a linear relationship.
principles.application: Velocity-time graph is a straight line with slope = $a$.
principles.example: If $a = 5$ m/s² and $v_i = 10$ m/s: at $t=1$s, $v=15$ m/s; at $t=2$s, $v=20$ m/s; at $t=3$s, $v=25$ m/s. Velocity increases by 5 m/s each second steadily.

principles.statement: Under constant acceleration, position follows a parabolic pattern: $x = x_i + v_i t + \frac{1}{2}at^2$. This is a quadratic relationship.
principles.example: Ball dropped from rest: falls 4.9 m in 1st second, 14.7 m in first 2 seconds (not linear—accelerating downward).

principles.statement: For constant acceleration only: $v_{\text{avg}} = \frac{v_i + v_f}{2}$. Average velocity is the arithmetic mean of initial and final velocities.
principles.application: This relationship only works for constant acceleration, not for varying acceleration.
principles.example: Start at $v_i = 10$ m/s, end at $v_f = 30$ m/s. Average velocity = $(10+30)/2 = 20$ m/s.

characteristics: Equal velocity changes in equal times

examples.explanation: Explicitly states constant acceleration
Indicates constant gravitational acceleration $g = 9.8$ m/s²
Constant deceleration

examples.process: Data: velocity increases by same amount each second
examples.explanation: Pattern indicates constant acceleration: $\Delta v$ same each $\Delta t$

classifications.behavior: Cannot use kinematic equations for constant $a$.

examples.explanation: Acceleration changing—not constant
Acceleration direction constantly changing—not constant
Acceleration increases as mass decreases—not constant

worked_examples.title: Recognizing Constant Acceleration
worked_examples.problem: Which scenarios involve constant acceleration? (a) Ball dropped from building, (b) Car traveling at 60 km/h on highway, (c) Elevator starting upward with constant acceleration for 2 seconds, (d) Person walking at varying speed.

step_by_step.explanation: Free fall → constant gravitational acceleration $g = 9.8$ m/s² downward. YES, constant acceleration.
Constant velocity → acceleration = 0 (which is constant!). YES, constant acceleration (zero acceleration).
Explicitly stated 'constant acceleration.' YES, constant acceleration.
Varying speed → changing velocity → changing acceleration (not constant). NO, not constant acceleration.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a), (b), and (c) involve constant acceleration. (d) does not.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Constant acceleration includes zero acceleration (constant velocity is special case). Look for uniform motion, free fall, or explicit statement of constant/uniform acceleration.

image.alt: Graph showing linear velocity change and parabolic position change
image.caption: Constant acceleration: v-t graph is straight line, x-t graph is parabola

sections.introduction: Four fundamental equations describe all constant acceleration motion. These equations are the primary tools for solving kinematics problems.

key_concept.definition: The kinematic equations are four formulas that relate the five key variables of constant acceleration motion: $v_i$ (initial velocity), $v_f$ (final velocity), $a$ (acceleration), $\Delta t$ (time interval), and $\Delta x$ (displacement). Each equation contains four of these five variables.
key_concept.context: These equations are derived from the definitions of velocity and acceleration combined with the fact that acceleration is constant. They're extremely powerful—knowing any three variables allows finding the other two. Choosing the right equation is key to efficient problem-solving.

principles.statement:
For constant acceleration motion:
(1) $v_f = v_i + a\Delta t$ [missing $\Delta x$]
(2) $\Delta x = v_i \Delta t + \frac{1}{2}a(\Delta t)^2$ [missing $v_f$]
(3) $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2a\Delta x$ [missing $\Delta t$]
(4) $\Delta x = \frac{1}{2}(v_i + v_f)\Delta t$ [missing $a$]
principles.application: Choose equation based on which variables are known and which you need to find.
principles.example: Know $v_i$, $a$, $\Delta t$, need $v_f$? Use equation (1). Know $v_i$, $v_f$, $a$, need $\Delta x$? Use equation (3).

principles.statement: Each of the four equations includes four variables and omits one. Choose the equation that omits the variable you don't know and don't need.
principles.application: Identify: what do I know? What do I need? Which variable is neither? Use that equation.
principles.example: Know $v_i$, $v_f$, $\Delta x$; need $a$; don't know or need $\Delta t$. Use equation (3) which doesn't include $\Delta t$.

principles.principle: Equations Apply Only for Constant Acceleration
principles.statement: These equations are valid ONLY when acceleration is constant. Do not use for varying acceleration.
principles.application: Always verify acceleration is constant before using kinematic equations.
principles.example: Free fall: constant $a$ → equations work ✓. Pendulum: varying $a$ → equations don't work ✗.

principles.statement: All variables are vectors (in 1D, use + and -). Consistent sign convention essential: choose positive direction, stick with it.
principles.application: Before calculating, define positive direction. Assign signs to all velocities and accelerations accordingly.
principles.example: Upward = positive. Then: $v$ upward = +, $v$ downward = -, gravity $a = -9.8$ m/s² (downward).

examples.explanation: You know $v_i$, $a$, and either $v_f$ or $\Delta t$, and you don't need $\Delta x$.
Given: $v_i = 5$ m/s, $a = 3$ m/s², $\Delta t = 4$ s. Find: $v_f = 5 + 3(4) = 17$ m/s
Rearrange: $\Delta t = \frac{v_f - v_i}{a}$. Given: $v_i = 10$ m/s, $v_f = 40$ m/s, $a = 5$ m/s². Find: $\Delta t = \frac{40-10}{5} = 6$ s
You know $v_i$, $a$, and either $\Delta x$ or $\Delta t$, and you don't know or need $v_f$.
$v_i = 0$, so $\Delta x = \frac{1}{2}a(\Delta t)^2$. For gravity: $\Delta x = \frac{1}{2}(-9.8)(\Delta t)^2$ (negative = downward)

classifications.behavior: Finds velocity or displacement without needing time.

examples.explanation: You know $v_i$, $a$, and either $v_f$ or $\Delta x$, and you don't know or need $\Delta t$.
Car braking to rest: $v_f = 0$. Rearrange: $\Delta x = \frac{v_f^2 - v_i^2}{2a} = \frac{0 - v_i^2}{2a} = -\frac{v_i^2}{2a}$ (negative $a$ for braking)
You know $v_i$, $v_f$, and either $\Delta x$ or $\Delta t$, and you don't know or need $a$.
Rearrange: $\Delta t = \frac{2\Delta x}{v_i + v_f}$. Given: $\Delta x = 120$ m, $v_i = 20$ m/s, $v_f = 40$ m/s. Find: $\Delta t = \frac{2(120)}{20+40} = \frac{240}{60} = 4$ s

worked_examples.title: Choosing and Using the Right Equation
worked_examples.problem: A car accelerates from rest at $a = 4$ m/s² for 6 seconds. Find: (a) final velocity, (b) displacement.

step_by_step.explanation: $v_i = 0$ (from rest), $a = 4$ m/s², $\Delta t = 6$ s
Known: $v_i$, $a$, $\Delta t$. Need: $v_f$. Don't need: $\Delta x$. Use equation (1): $v_f = v_i + a\Delta t$
Known: $v_i$, $a$, $\Delta t$ (and now $v_f$ from part a). Can use equation (2) or (4). Using (2): $\Delta x = v_i \Delta t + \frac{1}{2}a(\Delta t)^2$
Using equation (4): $\Delta x = \frac{1}{2}(v_i + v_f)\Delta t = \frac{1}{2}(0 + 24)(6) = \frac{1}{2}(24)(6) = 72$ m ✓ Same answer

worked_examples.concept_applied: From rest means $v_i = 0$. Use equation (1) for velocity. Use equation (2) or (4) for displacement. Multiple paths to same answer.

worked_examples.title: Problem Without Time
worked_examples.problem: A car traveling at 25 m/s brakes with $a = -5$ m/s² until it stops. How far does it travel while braking?

step_by_step.explanation: $v_i = 25$ m/s, $v_f = 0$ (stops), $a = -5$ m/s². Unknown: $\Delta x$. Time not given and not needed.
Use equation (3): $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2a\Delta x$
$\Delta x = \frac{v_f^2 - v_i^2}{2a}$
Positive displacement—car moved forward while braking (still in positive direction, just slowing down).

worked_examples.concept_applied: When time is neither given nor needed, use equation (3) which omits time. 'Stops' means $v_f = 0$.

image.caption: Four kinematic equations: each contains four of five variables (vi, vf, a, Δt, Δx)

sections.introduction: A systematic approach ensures successful solution of kinematics problems. Following organized steps reduces errors and clarifies thinking.

key_concept.definition: The problem-solving process for constant acceleration: (1) Read and visualize, (2) List known and unknown variables, (3) Choose appropriate equation, (4) Solve algebraically, (5) Substitute numbers with units, (6) Check answer for reasonableness.
key_concept.context: Kinematics problems can seem complex, but systematic approach makes them manageable. Organization is key—messy work leads to mistakes. Clear, step-by-step method ensures success.

process_flow.description: Read carefully. Identify what's happening. Sketch if helpful.
process_flow.mechanism: Understand the physical situation before starting calculations.
applications: Identify: Is object speeding up, slowing down, or changing direction?
Note: What is given? What is asked?
Sketch: Draw motion diagram or position axis if helpful

process_flow.process: Establish Reference Frame and Sign Convention
process_flow.description: Choose origin and positive direction. Assign signs to all vector quantities consistently.
process_flow.mechanism: Prevents sign errors—the most common mistake.
applications: Gravity: always $a = -9.8$ m/s² if upward is positive

process_flow.process: List Known Variables with Symbols and Values
process_flow.description: Write out: $v_i = ?$, $v_f = ?$, $a = ?$, $\Delta t = ?$, $\Delta x = ?$. Fill in what's known, mark what's unknown.
process_flow.mechanism: Organizes information. Makes it clear which equation to use.
process_flow.result: Complete inventory of knowns and unknowns.
applications: Identify which variable you need to find

process_flow.description: Choose equation that contains known variables and the unknown you're solving for, and omits the variable you neither know nor need.
applications: Count: How many knowns? (Need 3 to find 4th)
Identify: Which variable is neither known nor needed? Use equation that omits it.
If multiple equations work, choose simplest

process_flow.description: Rearrange equation to isolate unknown variable BEFORE substituting numbers.
process_flow.mechanism: Clearer, fewer arithmetic errors, easier to check work.
process_flow.result: Formula for unknown in terms of knowns.
applications: Example: From $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2a\Delta x$, get $\Delta x = \frac{v_f^2 - v_i^2}{2a}$ before inserting values

process_flow.description: Insert numerical values with units. Calculate carefully.
process_flow.mechanism: Units help catch errors. Include throughout calculation.
applications: Check units: if finding displacement, answer should be in meters

process_flow.description: Does answer make sense? Right magnitude? Right sign? Right units?
process_flow.mechanism: Catches calculation errors and conceptual mistakes.
applications: Negative displacement when moving backward? Check sign convention.
Car stopping in 1000 m when braking from 20 m/s? Too far—recheck.
Falling object reaches -200 m/s in 1 s? Way too fast—error somewhere.

worked_examples.title: Complete Problem-Solving Example
worked_examples.problem: A car traveling at 20 m/s begins braking with constant acceleration of -4 m/s². (a) How long until it stops? (b) How far does it travel while braking?

step_by_step.explanation: Car slowing down from 20 m/s to 0 (stopping) with constant deceleration.
Forward (direction of initial motion) = positive. Backward = negative. Braking opposes motion → $a$ is negative.
$v_i = +20$ m/s (moving forward), $v_f = 0$ (stops), $a = -4$ m/s² (braking), $\Delta t = ?$ (part a), $\Delta x = ?$ (part b)
Know: $v_i$, $v_f$, $a$. Need: $\Delta t$. Don't need: $\Delta x$. Use equation (1): $v_f = v_i + a\Delta t$
$v_f = v_i + a\Delta t$ → $a\Delta t = v_f - v_i$ → $\Delta t = \frac{v_f - v_i}{a}$
$\Delta t = \frac{0 - 20}{-4} = \frac{-20 \text{ m/s}}{-4 \text{ m/s}^2} = 5$ s
5 seconds to stop from 20 m/s with deceleration of 4 m/s²? Reasonable ✓. Velocity decreases 4 m/s each second: 20→16→12→8→4→0 in 5 seconds ✓
Know: $v_i$, $v_f$, $a$ (and now $\Delta t$ from part a). Need: $\Delta x$. Can use equation (3) or (4). Using (3): $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2a\Delta x$
$\Delta x = \frac{v_f^2 - v_i^2}{2a}$
50 m braking distance from 20 m/s? Reasonable ✓. Positive (moved forward while braking) ✓

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) $\Delta t = 5$ s (time to stop), (b) $\Delta x = 50$ m (braking distance)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Systematic approach: list variables, choose equations, solve algebraically first, check answer. Used two different equations for two parts.

image.caption: Problem-solving strategy: Understand → List variables → Choose equation → Solve → Check

sections.introduction: Free fall is one of the most important applications of constant acceleration. All objects near Earth's surface fall with the same constant acceleration.

key_concept.definition: Free fall is motion under the influence of gravity alone, with no other forces (ignoring air resistance). Near Earth's surface, all objects in free fall have the same constant downward acceleration: $g = 9.8$ m/s² (often approximated as 10 m/s² for simpler calculations).
key_concept.context: Free fall includes: objects dropped from rest, objects thrown downward, objects thrown upward (on the way up, at the peak, and on the way down—always $a = -g$), and objects thrown horizontally (vertical component). The key insight: acceleration is constant throughout, making this a perfect application of kinematic equations.

principles.statement: Near Earth's surface (and ignoring air resistance), $g = 9.8$ m/s² downward, regardless of object's mass, velocity, or direction of motion.
principles.application: Use $a = -9.8$ m/s² (if upward is positive) in all kinematic equations for free fall.
principles.example: Feather and hammer (in vacuum): both fall with same acceleration. Ball thrown upward: $a = -9.8$ m/s² even while going up.

principles.statement: Typical convention: upward = positive, downward = negative. Then gravity: $a = -g = -9.8$ m/s². Upward velocities are +, downward velocities are -.
principles.application: Stick to this convention consistently throughout problem.
principles.example: Ball thrown upward: $v_i = +15$ m/s (upward), $a = -9.8$ m/s² (downward gravity). Ball dropped: $v_i = 0$, $a = -9.8$ m/s².

principles.principle: Acceleration Is Same Going Up and Coming Down
principles.statement: Common misconception: acceleration different on way up vs way down. Reality: $a = -g$ constantly throughout.
principles.application: Use same acceleration value for entire motion.
principles.example: Ball thrown upward: going up ($a = -9.8$ m/s²), at peak ($a = -9.8$ m/s²), coming down ($a = -9.8$ m/s²). Constant!

principles.statement: At highest point, velocity momentarily zero, but acceleration is still $-9.8$ m/s² (not zero!).
principles.application: At peak: $v_f = 0$ for upward portion. Don't confuse with $a = 0$.
principles.example: Ball tossed upward: at peak, $v = 0$ (stopped for instant), but $a = -9.8$ m/s² still pulling downward, causing it to fall back.

principles.statement: Object thrown upward: time to rise = time to fall back to same height. Speed when returning = initial upward speed (magnitude).
principles.application: Can use symmetry to simplify some problems.
principles.example: Throw ball upward at +20 m/s. At same height on way down: $v = -20$ m/s (same magnitude, opposite direction).

worked_examples.title: Object Dropped from Rest
worked_examples.problem: A ball is dropped from a height of 45 m. (a) How long does it take to hit the ground? (b) What is its velocity when it hits?

step_by_step.explanation: Upward = +, downward = -. Origin at ground level. Dropped from rest: $v_i = 0$. Falls downward: $\Delta x = -45$ m (displacement downward). $a = -9.8$ m/s²
$v_i = 0$, $a = -9.8$ m/s², $\Delta x = -45$ m, $\Delta t = ?$ (part a), $v_f = ?$ (part b)
Know: $v_i$, $a$, $\Delta x$. Need: $\Delta t$. Don't need: $v_f$. Use equation (2): $\Delta x = v_i \Delta t + \frac{1}{2}a(\Delta t)^2$
$v_i = 0$, so $\Delta x = \frac{1}{2}a(\Delta t)^2$. Rearrange: $(\Delta t)^2 = \frac{2\Delta x}{a}$
Use equation (1): $v_f = v_i + a\Delta t = 0 + (-9.8)(3.03)$
Use equation (3): $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2a\Delta x = 0 + 2(-9.8)(-45) = 882$. $v_f = -\sqrt{882} = -29.7$ m/s (take negative root because moving downward)

worked_examples.concept_applied: Dropped from rest: $v_i = 0$. Downward displacement and velocity are negative. Used equation (2) for time, equation (1) or (3) for velocity.

worked_examples.title: Object Thrown Upward
worked_examples.problem: A ball is thrown upward with initial velocity +25 m/s. (a) How high does it go? (b) How long until it returns to starting height?

step_by_step.explanation: Upward = +. $v_i = +25$ m/s (upward), $a = -9.8$ m/s² (gravity downward)
At peak: $v_f = 0$ (momentarily stops). Know: $v_i = +25$ m/s, $v_f = 0$, $a = -9.8$ m/s². Need: $\Delta x$ (height). Use equation (3): $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2a\Delta x$

Symmetry: time up = time down. Find time to peak, double it. Or: use full motion. At return to start: $\Delta x = 0$ (back to starting height). Know: $v_i = 25$ m/s, $a = -9.8$ m/s², $\Delta x = 0$. Use equation (2).
$0 = 25\Delta t + \frac{1}{2}(-9.8)(\Delta t)^2$ → $0 = 25\Delta t - 4.9(\Delta t)^2$ → $0 = \Delta t(25 - 4.9\Delta t)$. Solutions: $\Delta t = 0$ (start) or $25 - 4.9\Delta t = 0$

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Maximum height = 31.9 m, (b) Returns to start in 5.10 s
worked_examples.concept_applied: Upward throw: at peak $v = 0$. Use equation (3) for max height. Symmetry or $\Delta x = 0$ for total time.

worked_examples.title: Finding Landing Velocity
worked_examples.problem: A ball is thrown downward from a 60 m tall building with initial velocity -15 m/s. What is its velocity when it hits the ground?

step_by_step.explanation: Downward = negative. $v_i = -15$ m/s (thrown downward), $\Delta x = -60$ m (falls 60 m down), $a = -9.8$ m/s²
Know: $v_i$, $a$, $\Delta x$. Need: $v_f$. Don't need time. Use equation (3): $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2a\Delta x$

worked_examples.concept_applied: Thrown downward: initial velocity already negative. Both $v_i$ and $a$ negative. Final velocity more negative (higher downward speed).

image.caption: Free fall: constant downward acceleration g = 9.8 m/s² throughout entire motion (up, peak, down)

sections.section_title: Common Mistakes and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Certain errors appear frequently in constant acceleration problems. Awareness and careful work prevent these mistakes.

categories.description: Most common error—inconsistent or incorrect signs.

examples.explanation: Using $a = +9.8$ m/s² for gravity when upward is positive (should be $a = -9.8$ m/s²)
Establish reference frame first. Stick to it consistently. Gravity always opposes upward direction: if up = +, then $a = -g$.
Write sign convention clearly at start. Check: does acceleration oppose or align with positive direction?
Using final velocity when equation needs initial velocity, or vice versa
Subscripts matter: $v_i$ = velocity at START of time interval. $v_f$ = velocity at END of time interval. Read problem carefully.

categories.description: Believing acceleration is zero at highest point.

examples.explanation: 'At the peak, the ball stops, so acceleration must be zero.'
At peak: velocity = 0 (momentarily), but acceleration = $-g$ still! Gravity doesn't stop pulling. That's why ball comes back down.

categories.type: Mistake: Forgetting to Square or Square Root

examples.explanation: Using $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2a\Delta x$ but forgetting to take square root at end: answer is $v_f^2$, not $v_f$
Equation (3) gives $v^2$. To find $v$, must take square root: $v_f = \pm\sqrt{v_i^2 + 2a\Delta x}$. Choose sign based on direction.

categories.description: Choosing equation that doesn't match knowns/unknowns.

examples.explanation: Trying to use equation (1) when time is neither known nor asked for (should use equation 3)
Count variables: need 3 known to find 4th. Choose equation containing those 3 knowns + 1 unknown, omitting the variable you don't have/need.
Using velocity in km/h with acceleration in m/s² without converting
Convert all quantities to consistent units before calculating. Standard: m, m/s, m/s², s.

summary: Constant acceleration motion occurs when acceleration remains unchanged throughout motion. This produces linear velocity change ($v = v_i + at$) and quadratic position change (parabolic $x$-$t$ graph). Five variables describe motion: initial velocity ($v_i$), final velocity ($v_f$), acceleration ($a$), time interval ($\Delta t$), and displacement ($\Delta x$). Four kinematic equations relate these variables, each containing four of the five: (1) $v_f = v_i + a\Delta t$ [omits $\Delta x$], (2) $\Delta x = v_i \Delta t + \frac{1}{2}a(\Delta t)^2$ [omits $v_f$], (3) $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2a\Delta x$ [omits $\Delta t$], (4) $\Delta x = \frac{1}{2}(v_i + v_f)\Delta t$ [omits $a$]. Problem-solving strategy: (1) understand situation, (2) establish reference frame and sign convention, (3) list known variables, (4) choose equation that contains knowns and unknown while omitting variable you don't have/need, (5) solve algebraically first, (6) substitute values with units, (7) check reasonableness. Free fall is important application: all objects near Earth's surface fall with constant acceleration $g = 9.8$ m/s² downward (often approximated as 10 m/s²). With upward = positive convention: $a = -g = -9.8$ m/s² always. Key free fall concepts: acceleration constant throughout entire motion (up, peak, down); at peak velocity = 0 but acceleration still = $-g$ (not zero); symmetry for vertical throws (time up = time down, return speed = launch speed). Common mistakes to avoid: sign errors (most common—establish and follow sign convention), confusing $v_i$ and $v_f$, thinking $a = 0$ at peak (wrong—still $a = -g$), forgetting to square root when using equation (3), choosing wrong equation for given knowns/unknowns, inconsistent units. Always check answer for correct sign, reasonable magnitude, and proper units.
